Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Surgical Cognitive Simulation Training in Surgical Trainees

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, general surgical trainees in years 3–5 from the West Midlands Deanery were recruited.

Participants.evidence: general surgical trainees in years 3–5 from the West Midlands Deanery were recruited.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to an intervention group receiving SCS training or a control group without training.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the impact of surgical cognitive simulation (SCS) training on surgical skills.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in procedure-based assessment scores, evaluated over four months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a random number generator, and assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Blinding.evidence: assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between January and June 2021, 21 participants were recruited, with 10 assigned to the intervention group and 11 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Complete data were available for 7 participants in each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated a statistically significant improvement in 11 of 16 assessment domains (P < 0.050) and a mean reduction in procedure time (–15.98 vs. –1.14 min; P = 0.024).

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by Health Education England (West Midlands) and supported by a Fellowship from the Alan Turing Institute and an MRC Confidence in Concept Award.
